quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: Teams that learn faster and integrate that learning faster will win. It's not about the team that moves fast, it's the team that learns fast. Learning velocity is the key competitive advantage.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: A lot of what passes for product strategy is actually just prioritized lists. Real strategy is about making hard trade-offs and saying what you won't do. Most companies avoid that because it's uncomfortable.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: Healthy teams have psychological safety but they also have tension. You need both. If there's no tension, you're probably not pushing hard enough on the problem. Productive disagreement is a sign of a good team.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: The best product teams I've seen have a shared understanding of what good looks like. They're not constantly debating fundamentals. They have enough alignment that they can move fast on the details.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: Outcome-based roadmaps only work if you have outcome-literate organizations. Most companies aren't ready for it. They need the scaffolding of output planning before they can graduate to outcomes.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: When I see product teams struggling, it's rarely about the team itself. It's usually about the surrounding context - unclear strategy, shifting priorities, too many dependencies. The team is a symptom, not the cause.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: The irony of agile is that many companies adopted the ceremonies but not the mindset. Daily standups with a waterfall planning process. Sprint retros that never lead to change. The practices without the principles.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: Technical debt isn't actually technical. It's a business decision. When leadership understands that they're borrowing against future velocity, they make different choices. Framing matters.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: Product managers often try to optimize for shipping features. But the best ones optimize for creating clarity. Clarity about what we're building, why, and what success looks like. Features follow from clarity.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: High-performing teams don't just move fast. They have tight feedback loops. They ship something small, learn from it, and iterate. The cycle time from idea to learning is the metric that matters most.

quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.text: Most product debates aren't actually about the product. They're about status, territory, or fear of being wrong. Once you recognize that, you can address the real issue instead of arguing about features.

takeaways: Learning velocity beats shipping velocity - teams that learn faster win
Real strategy means making hard trade-offs, not maintaining prioritized lists
Struggling teams are usually symptoms of organizational problems, not the cause
Outcome-based roadmaps require outcome-literate organizations - most aren't ready
Product debates are often proxies for status or fear - address the underlying issue

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the dogma that all teams should use outcome-based roadmaps - most orgs aren't ready
Exposes how agile adoption often fails by keeping ceremonies without the mindset
